actions-list.actionItem: The House proceeded with further one minute speeches.
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.

actions-list.header: On passage Passed by the Yeas and Nays: 220
On motion to recommit Failed by the Yeas and Nays: 211

actions-list.actionItem: Considered as unfinished business. H.R. 22 — "To amend the National Voter Registration Act of 1993 to require proof of United States citizenship to register an individual to vote in elections for Federal office, and for other purposes."
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.

actions-list.header: On motion that the House agree to the Senate amendment Agreed to by the Yeas and Nays: 216

actions-list.actionItem: Pursuant to clause 1(c) of rule XIX, the House resumed consideration of H. Con. Res. 14.
The Chair announced the unfinished business was the question on agreeing to the Senate amendment to H. Con. Res. 14, if ordered, motion to recommit H.R. 22, and passage of H.R. 22, if ordered.

At the conclusion of debate on H.R. 22, the Chair put the question on motion to recommit and by voice vote, announced the noes had prevailed. Ms. Johnson (TX) demanded the yeas and nays and the Chair postponed further proceedings until a time to be announced.
The previous question on the motion to recommit was ordered pursuant to clause 2(b) of rule XIX.
Ms. Johnson (TX) moved to recommit to the Committee on House Administration.
The previous question was ordered pursuant to the rule.
The House proceeded with one hour of debate on H.R. 22.

Rule provides for consideration of S.J. Res. 18, S.J. Res. 28, H.R. 1526 and H.R. 22. The resolution provides for consideration of H.R. 22, H.R. 1526, S.J. Res. 18, and S.J. Res. 28 under a closed rule. The resolution provides for one hour of debate on each measure and one motion to recommit on H.R. 22 and H.R. 1526, and one motion to commit on S.J. Res. 18 and S.J. Res. 28.

Considered under the provisions of rule H. Res. 294. H.R. 22 — "To amend the National Voter Registration Act of 1993 to require proof of United States citizenship to register an individual to vote in elections for Federal office, and for other purposes."
The House proceeded with one minute speeches which by direction of the Chair, would be limited to 5 per side of the aisle.
The Chair designated Mr. McGarvey to lead the Members in reciting the Pledge of Allegiance to the Flag.
The Speaker announced approval of the Journal.  Pursuant to clause 1, rule I, the Journal stands approved.
Today's prayer was offered by Dr. Michael Gossett, Green Acres Baptist Church, Tyler, Texas.
The House convened, starting a new legislative day.
